bioghist.p: The Settlement Music School is a private organization whose purpose is to provide music instruction for children and adults regardless of ability to pay. In its early years a major function was to assist immigrants in finding employment. The school was incorporated in 1913, and moved into its present building on Queen Street in 1917. Branches in Germantown and Frankford were established in 1951. Although founded primarily for the benefit of school-aged children, Settlement developed a conservatory division offering pre-professional training that was of sufficient stature to serve as the nucleus of the Curtis Institute of Music, established in 1924.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of records, sound, and visual recordings related to Settlement Music School and various performances. Administrative records include Board and Executive Committee minutes (primarily from 1975-1986, but with miscellaneous older minutes), reports, copies of the school's by-laws, and memoranda. There is correspondence and memoranda from the school's directors and other school staff. Teaching materials include: course lists and syllabi; teachers' timesheets; and student records, such as registration forms, schedules, grade sheets, scholarship application letters, attendance and absence records. Performance- and event-related materials include: correspondence and memoranda, schedules, programs, guest lists, and other planning records, as well as 19 boxes of audio reels of performances, and some radio spots, 1955-1987. Many of the reels are accompanied by printed concert programs. The collection also includes several films and video recordings. There are a number of printed and publicity materials, such as brochures, clippings and press releases from Settlement Music School and miscellaneous printed materials from conferences and other community organizations. The collection also includes a letterfile box of correspondence of James P. Carson, Secretary of the Carson College for Orphan Girls.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
